bestBHT.bht: In this account, we encounter a man who is completely under the power of an unclean spirit, a demon. The contrast between the man's impurity and the glory of Christ is evident. We often see evil spirits associated with impurity throughout Scripture. The demon cried out in fear and envy at the success of Christ's ministry and in dread of His overwhelming presence. These spirits sometimes gather in religious settings with no good intentions, seeking to disrupt the preacher and hinder the impact of God's word.

Henry Alford: We may observe that this epithet often occurs under strong contrast to His Majesty and glory."
The demons having a common cause."
He did not injure him at all.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In an unclean spirit"—that is, so entirely under demoniacal power that his personality was sunk for the time in that of the spirit.
The frequency with which this character of "impurity" is ascribed to evil spirits.
Marvin Vincent: With an unclean spirit (å̓í ðíåṍìáôé á̓êáèá́ñôùͅ)
Philip Schaff: A man with an unclean spirit . Lit., ‘in an unclean spirit,’ in his power, in intimate union with him. See on Matthew 4:24.
Archibald T. Robertson: In English we speak of our being in love, in drink, in his cups, etc.
Unclean spirit is used as synonymous with demon.
One wonders today if the degenerates and confirmed criminals so common now are not under the power of demons.
John Gill: He had a spirit of an unclean devil: so called, because he is impure in himself, and the cause of uncleanness in men, in which he delights.
Such spirits sometimes are where religious persons meet, but with no good design; either to disturb the preacher, or to divert the hearer, that the word may be unfruitful and unprofitable.

He cried out through dread of the majesty of Christ, whose presence he could not bear; and through grief and envy at the success of his ministration, and the influence it had upon the minds of men; and through fear of being dispossessed of the man, in whom he was.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 1:23, we see a man with an unclean spirit, completely under demonic power. This contrast between the man's impurity and the majesty of Christ is often observed throughout Scripture. The frequency with which evil spirits are associated with impurity is notable. The unclean spirit in this man cried out in fear and envy at the success of Christ's ministry, and in dread of His overwhelming presence. The demon's presence was intended to disrupt the preaching and hinder the impact of God's word on the hearers. Reflecting on this passage, one can't help but wonder if the power of demons is still at work in our world today.

In this account, we encounter a man who is completely under the power of an unclean spirit, a demon. The contrast between the man's impurity and the glory of Christ is evident. We often see evil spirits associated with impurity throughout Scripture. The demon cried out in fear and envy at the success of Christ's ministry and in dread of His overwhelming presence. These spirits sometimes gather in religious settings with no good intentions, seeking to disrupt the preacher and hinder the impact of God's word.

In this account, we witness a man under the complete control of an unclean spirit, a demon. The contrast between the man's impurity and the splendor of Christ is notable. Evil spirits are frequently associated with impurity throughout Scripture. The demon cried out in both fear and envy at the success of Christ's ministry and in dread of His overpowering presence. These spirits, driven by malice and envy, often seek to disrupt religious gatherings and hinder the effectiveness of God's word.

In this incident, a man with an unclean spirit, completely under demonic power, encounters Jesus. The stark contrast between the man's impurity and the majesty of Christ is evident. It is worth noting the frequent association of evil spirits with impurity in the Scriptures. The demon within the man cried out out of fear and envy in response to Christ's presence and the impact of His ministry. This highlights the malicious intentions of these spirits, often seeking to disrupt religious settings and hinder the effectiveness of God's Word.

In this encounter, a man is possessed by an unclean spirit that renders him completely under demonic power. This highlights the stark contrast between the man's impurity and the majesty of Christ. Throughout the Scriptures, there is a consistent association of evil spirits with impurity. The demon in the man cried out, driven by fear and envy at the success of Christ's ministry and the power of His presence. It raises the question of whether the power of demons is still at work in our world.
